3. 
For in the second paragraph (page VI) under the same 
heading Dr Shaw draws attention specifically to these 
misfortunes noting every instrumental failure or 
'peculiarity of procedure' which the records of obser-
vations disclose and I have but to consider his remarks 
in the order in which they stand. 
Mercurial thermometers are much more easily 
read than uncoloured spirit thermometers and they are 
less rapidly affected by the breath or proximity of the 
observer. The importance of these advantages in the 
cold darkness of an Antarctic winter constitutes a good 
and sufficient reason for the adoption of Mercury 
thermometers for routine observations, and the suggestion 
that this course was taken on account of the presence 
of an "index" in the spirit thermometer is entirely 
refuted. 
The Mercury thermometers can only be suggested 
to have failed on the rare occasions (at the Winter 
Quarters) when the temperature fell below - 40 F and 
on such occasions either an absolute reading of the 
Spirit thermometer or a corrected reading of the 
Mercury thermometer is available. 
Given proper corrections for both thermometers 
only a slight addition to the labour of reduction can 
have been occasioned by the course adopted and it is to 
be observed that Dr Chree (page 453 et seq) expresses no 
<u>doubt<\u>
